title: Tuesday, 5th September, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE11:04am

Hi! Welcome, hello, good morning, hey.

BE11:05am

Paul's in a meeting --an actual one! -- but promises to join shortly.

BE11:06am

Meaning I get to pick the picture, which today is ....

11:06 am
BE11:06am

BE11:06am

That's Ten Paternoster Square.

BE11:07am

The Eric Parry Architects-designed lump on the edge of St Paul's.

11:07 am
BE11:08am

It was formerly the office of the Takeover Panel, but now available to rent.

BE11:08am

At least I assume it is, as the Panel seems to have been disbanded.

BE11:08am

It's the only explanation I can think of why Aveva's takeover by Schneider was allowed to happen in total darkness.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

You remember this one! Deal was on in July 2015, then terminated in December 2015, then on again in June 2016, then terminated again within about a nanosecond.

BE11:09am

Now, it was never a stretch to speculate that the deal might be back on.

BE11:10am

But what we had was a wee bit more than speculation. Factiva shows me 23 separate reports in the mainstream press that over the past three months that Aveva was talking again to Schneider.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Was the speculation not specific enough to shake out a statement? Well, there was a target and a bidder and a likely structure so not really.

BE11:11am

Did Aveva have licence to stay schtum because it its foreign domicile falls outside the Panel's remit?

BE11:12am

(As happened -- much to our annoyance -- in Entertainment One.)

11:11 am
BE11:12am

Well, no. Last I checked Aveva's HQ's in Cambridge.

BE11:12am

And does Aveva have a history of being a bit sparing?

BE11:13am

Yup. You'll remember on either the first or second approach that they stayed shtumn because the (widely reported) rumour was a takeover when in fact they were talking about a reverse into a division that still involved ceding control.

11:13 am
BE11:14am

Pretty much identical to today's structure, in fact.

BE11:15am

The difference this time seems to be that all the loose ends have been tied beforehand, so there's a better chance for completion. Is that worth maintaining a false market for a few months? Dunno.

BE11:15am

Have some sellside. Barclays.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

This morning AVEVA announced again a reverse merger with the Schneider Electric Software Business, at least the third time this has been officially discussed by the company and following the initial attempt in 2015. The deal structure is very similar to 2015, however, management believes this time that the separation of the Schneider assets over the intervening period makes such a transaction possible to complete. The prospectus is tomorrow, the vote will be 29 September and the deal is expected to close by the end of the year – this time the transaction looks likely to happen.

BE11:15am

Like last time, Schneider will pay AVEVA £550m in cash or roughly 858p per share, effectively a premium for control. Furthermore, AVEVA will distribute £100m of existing cash prior to the merger to shareholders, or 156p. In addition AVEVA will issue 97.4m shares to Schneider so that Schneider will own 60% of the combined entity. In total AVEVA shareholders will receive 1,014p and 40% of the combined entity. This is down from the 46.5% last time around, primarily as Schneider is including an additional mid-stream oil & gas business in the merger. The transaction is described as being marginally earnings dilutive in the first full year, with opportunity for synergies beyond that. However, note that this is after the return of £550m which effectively acts as a premium paid by Schneider for control of the business. AVEVA shareholders receive 858p for ceding control and have an earnings stream per share broadly equivalent to before. As last time, we therefore see AVEVA as by far the key beneficiary in this deal. For more information, please refer to our note on the initial merger attempts, M&A remains the theme in UK tech (21 July 2015).

BE11:15am

Excluding the premium payment, the total equity consideration for the additional issued shares to Schneider is £1,720m or 19x Schneider’s FY17A EBITA. However, we believe we should also look at an adjustment for the premium payment and on this basis, effectively Schneider is disposing of Schneider Software for £1,170m given the £550m cash return, while retaining the ability to participate in the upside (60% ownership). On a multiples basis, the net Schneider assets would on this basis be valued at 12.8x FY17A EBITA and 2.6x revenues, as we show below. This is considerably below the 20x and 5.0x multiples we calculate AVEVA to be trading on.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

AVEVA and Schneider are currently selecting a new CEO for the combined entity with “proven track record and experience in managing a global software business”. The current CEO, James Kidd, will continue in its role until the board appoints a new CEO. He will then become Deputy CEO and CFO. David Ward will also continue in his role as CFO until the appointment of a new CEO, following which he is intended to step down from the Board and be appointed to the role of Company Secretary.

BE11:16am

And Citi.

BE11:16am

A Balance Portfolio — In FY17, Schneider Software generated revenues and EBITA of £441.7 million of £91.2 million respectively (25.3% margin). The combined business will create a leading industrial software business (£657.5m of revenues in FY17; £216m Aveva standalone) and adj. EBITA of £145.8 (£54.7m Aveva standalone in FY17) with 22.2% margin (20.6% for Aveva) with a more balanced portfolio. On a geographic basis, this would expand Aveva’s geographic footprint in Americas (39% from 15%) at the same time diversifying away from oil & gas markets end markets and increasing profile into adjacent industrial end markets (e.g.) Chemicals, Mining and reducing its cyclicality, in our view.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Immediate Value in form of Cash Returns, Attractive Valuation — The deal will generate immediate value to Aveva's existing shareholders' in form of cash distribution of £550m (858p) alongside Aveva’s excess net cash (156p per share, we estimate) bringing total potential cash returns of 1,014p. Adjusting this from current price of 1,920p, this values Aveva at 12x FY18e PE (end-March) and EV/Recurring Revenues

BE11:17am

And Goldman.

BE11:17am

Financial details of the deal are as follows: Aveva will acquire Schneider Software on a debt-free basis, with Schneider Electric giving £550mn (£8.58 per share for Aveva’s shareholders) in cash to Aveva shareholders. This will lead to Schneider Electric owning 60% of Aveva Group post the transaction. The cash payment from Schneider Electric combined with cash from Aveva’s balance sheet (£100mn i.e. £1.56 per share) implies a total cash of 1,014p/share, which will be distributed to Aveva’s shareholders upon completion of the deal. We calculate that the deal values the combined entity at c.4.3x EV/FY17 sales and standalone Aveva at c.9x EV/sales (FY17), at a premium to PLM software deals (median of c.3x since 2005), and towards the upper end of deal multiples in the broader software market (historic range of 5x-10x). We calculate the deal values Aveva standalone at a c.50% premium to current market value.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

While we don’t take any view on the probability of the acquisition closing, we would expect the deal to enhance Aveva’s exposure to the Americas market, result in diversification of its verticals and addition of scale and also improve the go-to market capability. In our view, this transaction continues to underscore the convergence and consolidation in the PLM and broader industrial software market.

BE11:19am

And MOST.

BE11:20am

The Schneider Electric Software business is made up of the former Invensys software assets (acquired in January 2014) and other SE software assets. SE has now also included the oil & gas pipeline management solutions, a division of Telvent that SE acquired in 2011. SES is a leading industrial software player, offering solutions
in both the process and batch manufacturing industries and the infrastructure market (power, water/wastewater & transportation infrastructure). In FY17 (31/03/17 y/e), Schneider Software reported revenues of $575.1m (£441.7m - using $/£ rate of 1.3021) and adj. EBITA of $118.8m (£91.2m), implying an operating margin of 20.7%. The top line declined in FY15-17 at a CAGR of -7.4%. Over FY15-17, the business has grown its support (maintenance) by +4.6%, but seen both services (-19.9%) and licences (-18.9%) decline. Licences are ~37% of FY17 revenues, with maintenance ~30% and Services ~30%. On margins, Schneider achieved an adj. EBITA margin of 20.6% in FY17 (up from 17.9% in FY15). In terms of the revenue split by geography, Schneider Software is 47% North America, 28% EMEA, 18% Asia Pacific, 4% Latam and 3% other. The business's end-market split is 47% Oil, Gas & Chemicals, 16% Food, Beverage & Pharma, 10% Engineering and 27% other. The business invests c. 18% of its revenues in R&D (vs. c. 13% at Aveva)

11:20 am
undefined
BE11:21am

Sigh.

BE11:23am

(In answer to your point earlier, @Mouselet, which I know was facetious but I'll take it anyway. We always like statements confirming stories. We don't like no statement when a story's accurate, and we also don't like PRs responding to a phone call pre publication rather than actual publication because this is quite a big disincentive for ever calling them again.)

11:22 am
BE11:23am

So anyway.

BE11:24am

FTSE going nowhere, sterling a bit down post services data .....

BE11:25am

This slightly odd RythmnOne US takeover wrapped up, as noted on the right.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Which we can come back to, but Next is also mentioned.

Next PLC (NXT:LSE): Last: 4,274, up 47 (+1.11%), High: 4,322, Low: 4,233, Volume: 188.84k
BE11:26am

Which seems to be a bounce more than anything, as the narrative about it being structurally snookered begins to reduce in volume.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

We've also got decent BRC data to support.

BE11:27am

August total retail LFL +1.3%, up from +0.9% in July

BE11:27am

Which I think backs up the recent Kantar apparel survey

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Here's UBS with the detail.

BE11:28am

August BRC was +1.3%, one of the best figures for some time, although against weak comps from a very warm August last year. This benefitted non-food rather than Food,
with the implied non-food LFL in August c2.2%, the best figure since last October. Online also had a good month, with 11% growth against a YTD average of +9%. Once again, in-store LFL was negative although less so than over the last 12-18 months. Generally though this remains an issue for non-food retailers, with store costs still rising

BE11:28am

Sectors which suffered last year, such as home furnishings, furniture and clothing, were the best performers this time around. The same may well be the case in September given the heatwave last year. Household appliances was the only category declining yoy, although this was still up on an LFL basis presumably reflecting the space closure programme at Dixons. Weakness in appliances was interestingly not from large appliances, which seemed to benefit from the uptick in consumer confidence. SDA was weaker, although this was more promotional last year.

11:28 am
BE11:29am

If food price inflation continues to edge lower then this is good news for disposable income. However, it seems too early to call the turn here given the recent appreciation of the euro, which could further fuel imported inflation. Further out, if £/$ remains close to 1.30, there may be less FX transaction pressure for the non-food retailers into cal.2018. There may be some comment here at the Next interims next week.

BE11:29am

They're Next buyers.

BE11:29am

With real wage growth slowing and unsecured lending likely to slow or contract, the already low savings ratio may provide little breathing room for the sector. The immediate focus, however, will be on comments from Next on the outlook and specifically on whether its Q2 Directory performance was a one-off. We think the selfhelp measures may have further to run and remain comfortable with our Buy rating

11:30 am
BE11:30am

(@FJP73: heard several names on that one, but not Next.)

BE11:32am

(@FJP: trying to find in the archive when we last wrote about that, and can't. Note also the CEO selldown at the back of June though.)

BE11:32am

And just before I move off the subject ....

11:32 am
BE11:33am

BE11:33am

Shamelessly stolen off The Twitter. Can't remember who. Sorry.

undefined
11:33 am
BE11:33am

Inmarsat, then.

BE11:35am

(@fjp73: theoretically, Next would make a lot of sense as it'd fit the non-brand model and fix the loss of leadership online. But I have to repeat that I hadn't heard that name.)

BE11:35am

......... Numis selling Inmarsat.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

John Karidis the analyst.

KS11:39am

(Bryce is currently experiencing some technical difficulties and will be right back in a moment)

KS11:39am

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Back!

BE11:05am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily thing with the typing.

BE11:42am

As in, no sign of overheat or whatever.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Note to self: don't criticise the Takeover Panel. Their powers are mysterious and beyond our comprehension.

BE11:43am

Anyway, bak to that Numis thing on Inmarsat.

BE11:44am

You'll remember Numis (as a house) have some history with satellite companies.

11:44 am
PM11:44am

(Embarassed smile back)

BE11:44am

Google Avanti for more on that. Oh, hello stranger.

PM11:44am

(Embarassed smile severely under-estimated meeting drag)

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Here -- at last! -- is Numis selling Isat.

BE11:45am

We initiate coverage of ISAT with a SELL rating and a 480p Target Price. Of course, we agree with management that demand for satellite connectivity will keep rising apace for years to come. Even so, relative to what the current share price implies, we see numerous reasons to be cautious about ISAT's revenue and EBITDA margin prospects, and its ability to cut yearly capex materially beyond the next few years.

BE11:46am

Reasons we are cautious about ISAT revenue prospects. In Maritime (43% of group EBITDA in FY16), FY19 and FY20 growth may well be +1.0% and +2.5% respectively or less, vs consensus on +2.5% and +4.4%. In Government (23%), we think ISAT's business with Boeing may not be growing fast enough to make up for ebbing takeor-pay revenue. In Enterprise (10%), ISAT has lost its strategic take-or-pay partner (RigNet). In Aviation (9%), price and service competition remain very intense; also we think ISAT may now be less bullish about prospects of its flagship Lufthansa contract.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Reasons we are cautious about ISAT's EBITDA margin outlook. In Aviation, ISAT expects margin to fall to the 40s percent level over the next five years (from 68% in FY16), yet consensus only expects 51%, 48% and 53%, FY17 to FY19. In Government, we think 2Q FY17 profitability was much less than ISAT's commentary implied, so this worries us with regard to future trends. In Maritime, the cost of incentivising strategic partners to win more ships will eat into the efficiency of bringing existing vessels on-net

BE11:46am

Our terminal year capex forecast is likely 10-20% more than most expect. Intense competition in In-Flight Connectivity is also shaping customer expectations in Maritime and Government. Also, GoGo now offers 15Mbps to each passenger globally but, for example, ISAT's European Aviation Network at launch will offer up to 75Mbps to a plane. Hence why ISAT's CEO expects capex cycles to shorten and intensify, and ISAT to keep spending on its global network. Lastly, ViaSat's technology allows its 2nd Gen satellite and its future 3rd Gen satellites to deploy spectrum dynamically (to maximise returns); instead, ISAT very likely needs more satellites to boost capacity regionally.

BE11:47am

● We see 35% share price downside. By FY19, vs consensus, we expect EBITDA and capex -8% and +5%, respectively, so our EBITDA-capex estimate is -43%. Also, we forecast flat DPS after FY17 and that this will be uncovered by FCF until after FY23. We value ISAT on a DCF basis because comparing valuation multiples means little, since 'peers' are at different stages of executing different business plans.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Contact Numis for the rest of it. Excellent, long, detailed note.

Inmarsat PLC (ISAT:LSE): Last: 701.00, down 34.5 (-4.69%), High: 735.00, Low: 683.50, Volume: 1.29m
undefined
11:48 am
PM11:48am

Is there a fresh reason for Provident Financial falling?

BE11:48am

(@wayneJ: I should perhaps point out that I'm on a PC I built myself out of spare parts that's running Windows XP Black. McAfee probably won't fly.)

BE11:48am

Not that I've seen, other than it's Provident.

11:48 am
Provident Financial PLC (PFG:LSE): Last: 810.50, down 45.5 (-5.32%), High: 857.50, Low: 779.50, Volume: 1.08m
BE11:49am

The Morses Club results the other day were interesting.

BE11:50am

The being that Morses has stepped up its sales force to take advantage of Provident's dissaray

11:50 am
PM11:50am

Makes sense

PM11:50am

BE11:50am

(@wayneJ: it's a legit licence key.)

11:50 am
PM11:50am

But it's back below six quid

Pearson (PSON:LSE): Last: 598.50, down 5 (-0.83%), High: 603.50, Low: 597.00, Volume: 315.29k
PM11:51am

There's a JPM note around, but I'm told it doesn't say much new

11:52 am
BE11:52am

(@wayneJ: nope. Not necessarily. Mine doesn't anyway.)

PM11:52am

See this RhythmOne deal has actually happened

PM11:53am

https://www.invest...1709050700048234P/

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Yeah, RhythmOne is now twice the size and just as questionable as a business model.

PM11:53am

It's RhythmOne taking over YuMe

PM11:53am

One third cash, two thirds stock

11:53 am
PM11:53am

I thought this would go down rather better than it has -- share price wise

BE11:54am

Quick line from Singer, who like.

PM11:54am

R One at just under 37p

11:54 am
BE11:55am

73p target. Didn't Singer do a very good online advertising note a few years back?

BE11:55am

YUME is a significant scale demand side platform (DSP) focused on video and with strong brand/agency relationships. It also has a position in the connected TV market that looks set to grow. Aside from the immediate cost synergies (savings $10 to 11m in FY19) RTHM will be looking to sell more of its inventory through YUME boosting returns further. The RTHM programmatic platform and international offering support this. Provided the transaction is completed by end of FY18 (target closing is calendar Q1) we expect combined revenues to reach c$500m in FY19 making RTHM one of the largest players. Based on synergies and market expectations for YUME, RTHM is acquiring the business on a c7.5x FY19 pre-synergy EBITDA multiple or c5x including synergies. This looks another very strong deal for RTHM that not only adds scale but also increases exposure to the demand side and video.

BE11:56am

....... once again, the archive proves unyielding.

11:56 am
undefined
BE11:57am

Redrow requested.

Redrow PLC (RDW:LSE): Last: 641.00, up 21 (+3.39%), High: 666.00, Low: 633.50, Volume: 1.36m
11:57 am
BE11:57am

It's a housebuilder and it's in a gamed market so you know the rest, right?

BE11:58am

Numbers a bit better than expected. Guidance a bit better. Divi a lot better.

BE11:58am

Peel Hunt to summarise.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Final results – group beat expectations with 20% revenue growth (+15%
completions), 23% rise in operating profit, 50bp rise in the operating margin to
19.4% and a 26% jump in PBT to £315m (vs £308m forecast). EPS climbs 27%
to c70p compared with our estimate of 68.1p. The biggest increase was saved for
the dividend, which rose 70% to 17p ahead of our expectation of 15p.
Balance sheet & Land bank – net debt was also better than expected at £73m
while the land bank advanced in the year by 100 plots to 26,100. In terms of
years the 15% rise in completions meant the length in years dropped to 4.9 years,
still a very comfortable level in our view.
Outlook & Forecasts – sales in the new financial year have started well with
volumes up 8% in the first nine weeks adding to the record order book, which
was up 14% year-on-year. As a result we are upping our PBT forecasts by 5-6%
for FY18-19 while our cash/net debt expectations also improve.
Performance & Valuation – The shares have been the second best performers
among the housebuilders so far in 2017 with a rise of 44% (second only to
Persimmon). However, they continue to look cheap as they are trading on a 15%
P/NAV discount vs the peer group while its RoE is in line with the sector
average. While the dividend yield is below average currently, we expect Redrow
to deliver the best growth over the next few years as the group takes its cover
down to 3x or below. We increase our target price to 740p and retain our Buy
recommendation.

BE11:58am

Sorry for lumpy formatting.

BE11:59am

And Canaccord.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

I'm not sorry for Canaccord, to clarify. I mean, "here's Canaccord."

BE11:59am

A strong set of results, around +3% ahead of expectations at the PBT level. The balance sheet was also stronger with net debt lower than expected, which also supported a higher than expected DPS at 17.0p (+70%). Recent trading and order book comments are strong with sales up by +8% over the last nine weeks. Focus will likely be on the revised medium term guidance. Management has rolled its guidance forward to FY 2020 and, assuming the market holds up, now expects revenue and PBT of £2.2bn and £430m respectively; the implied DPS would be 32p (almost a doubling of the dividend over three years). This guidance supports a continuing strengthening of the balance sheet, with net cash likely to be reached during FY 2019. Shares have enjoyed a strong run, up by c.+60% over the last twelve months with valuation now looking less attractive. However, these strong results and medium term guidance comments support the share price with consensus likely to move up by c.+6-8% for FY 2018. The group is delivering strongly and looks set to continuing to deliver in line with its guidance to FY 2020 supported by a strong land bank, assuming the market allows.

BE11:59am

Shares have enjoyed a very strong performance over the last twelve months, up by c.+60%. They have strongly outperformed the market and sector over the last twelve months. They reside on an FY2018E P/NAV multiple of c.1.55 times and offer a dividend yield of +c.3.5%.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

And Numis, I think are saying it's run a bit far.

BE12:00pm

In our view this is a good update and the new longer term guidance on profit and dividend is welcomed and we suspect will prove to be cautious – as has previously been the case. Post the upgrade the shares trade on a Dec 2018 P/NTAV of 1.35x, 6.9x PE and a yield of 4.2%. In our view Redrow continues to look undervalued versus the wider sector and management’s ability to under promise and over-deliver suggests that – if current trading remains robust – the group will see further upgrades.

undefined

PM12:01pm

PM12:01pm

Are we done for today?

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

I am, yes. Apologies for whatever we didn't tackle on the right.

PM12:02pm

PM12:02pm

Thanks for sticking with on the right

12:02 pm
PM12:02pm

Back tomorrow at 11am sharp

PM12:02pm

Bye

BE11:42am

Well, that was interesting. PC just completely shut down without warning.
